body: Opened a Jira for it - CAY-1942 https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CAY-1942
Applied. I did some cleanup per bd22051d26ca2062e7983561f1c137ef4ec03720 , but nothing major, mostly cosmetics and licensing. You can close the pull request. Thanks!
I committed the patches. We can close the pull request
I committed 0f11876 . Filter now works correctly. Good job! There are a few more things we may want to improve per CAY-1841. I'll comment in Jira (and we;ll track it under a new pull request)
Just applied. We can close this one. Great job!
Sorry, but It isn't a good solution. I've just found use case which causes a bug. I'm going to continue working on it.

Savva, while your latest solution is not wrong, I think we may piggyback on the existing functionality for managing file deletions implemented in FileProjectSaver.clearOldFiles(..). From looking at this code, 'clearOldFiles' works for renamed resources already. Just not for deleted resources. So maybe we can track deleted inside the Project object (not inside ProjectFileChangeTracker which is a modeler class dealing with unrelated stuff) ?
I don't think it's a good idea to add methods to ProjectSaver interface, but i don't know how to make deletion without it. Maybe I don't understand what you suggest.

Public methods - probably. I see no problem with adding internal non-public methods. Also what I am suggesting is to add extra state to Project (not ProjectSaver). ProjectSaver would just act on this state.

Hey Alex, thanks for the patches. would it be possible to open separate pull requests? E.g. "jacoco report" is a standalone thing. Refactoring and unit test improvements are perhaps candidates for separate pull request as well.

Committed in a squashed form. Good stuff! Noticed a few test failures though (on HSQL and MySQL) :

 Failed tests: 
  testForeignKey(org.apache.cayenne.merge.DropRelationshipToModelTest)
  testRemoveFKColumnWithoutRelationshipInDb(org.apache.cayenne.merge.DropColumnToModelTest)
committed. Pretty cool! for the record reports are stored under each module's target/site/jacoco-ut/

done. Good stuff. We can close this one.

Notice c669b95e3c33e9c639ee05ba124ff7d5a8ca5ed7 though - had to preserve those stupid casts, as Java 1.6 compiler can't do type inference well enough.

I think we are very close with the last commit. Still a bit of nitpicking... 
1. I suggest storing 'deletedDataMaps' in the Project, not in DataChannelDescriptor. The reason is - DataChannelDescriptor is used in Cayenne runtime, where there's no notion of "deleting a DataMap", so I don't want to expose that new API there. As Project doesn't deal with DataMaps directly, you might save deleted DataMaps as Resource's for instance.
2. I sorta understand the reason for renaming SaveUnit to Unit (since some units are "delete units") .. Still "Unit" is too generic. I'd keep SaveUnit, and if you want to distinguish save from delete, create another inner class - DeleteUnit or something (and indeed the two have different structure, so manybe there's no point to keep them as one class)
applied with a small refactoring as a separate commit
Unit tests failures are still happening even after applying #10. However I was able to narrow it down to java 6 tests. Doesn't happen on Java 7.
I've fixed tests
Applied. Thanks!
Applied with some cosmetic changes. We can close the pull request.

I committed "cayenne-project" part of this pull request. With one change - unusedResources doesn't have to be an ivar of FileProjectSaver. It is just a local variable.

I did not commit any changes to cayenne-modeler package, as the suggested behavior results in exceptions when trying to add/delete DataMaps in a new previously unsaved project:

Sorry, I forgot to test behavior in a new unsaved project. This commit should resolve exceptions. Also, maybe should I write some tests?
I suggest something like last commit. I would like to hear your remarks and instructions.
Just committed with a small addition - we need to clear the list of unused projects at the end of the save. We can close the pull request.
Yes. I've been sure that method deleteUnusedFiles(...) contained it. Also, should I write some tests?
There's a confusion here.. I already added the list clear code myself in my commit. Please check the sources. So the pull request can be closed.

You should remove the unrelated commits from your patch.

> Michael Gentry    Back-filled previously filed Board Reports for 2014.    ed8b7b0
> Michael Gentry    Initial draft for 9/2014 Board Report.  8eb8def

It's been several months since I've used git, but I believe one way to do this is to use

git rebase -i <commit before commits we want to remove/replace/adjust> 

in the branch you want to fix, and then delete the unwanted commits.

So for your specific incidence, you would "git rebase -i /60a1985be781246a11e0816eec4a9951f9b75e5d" and then delete the two lines containing mgr's board reports, leaving only your three commits.
I've done! Thank you a lot, Mike Kienenberger. Sorry for this confusion. I hope I will commit correctly next time.

This commit for Oracle DB.
Also I think we should add format like "yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.S", because e.g. MySQL JDBC driver can't convert java.sql.Timestamp from String, so we can do it ourselves.

Just did a review of the pull request. A few notes:
1. Thread safety: SimpleDateFormat is stateful and is not tread-safe. So we have no choice but to create formatters on the fly when checking the date. 
2. General design: would be great if CharType could convert String to Date, but then delegate the actual binding to a DateType (TimestampType, etc) instead of doing it on its own. If we don't do that, we'll bypass per-adapter ExtendedTypes. 

"2" concerns me. I am researching an approach of sharing ExtendedTypes between each other. And an alternative approach of  changing the expression syntax to explicitly indicate which literals are dates. JPA for instance supports JDBC escape syntax, which looks kind of ugly:

a = {d 'yyyy-mm-dd'}

We may need something better (??). So I guess we'll place this on hold until we decide on a better solution.

Thanks! 

Just pushed this pull request. We'll discuss the actual style checking on the dev list to include the community.

There was  one notable change that I made (10b64e876ebd62bb9ab0927ba6bb219eea45ea74) - we shouldn't be using "central" repo directly. It should all be proxied via objectstyle.org repo for consistency and performance.

Also in the future can we please "git merge --squash" the changes before submitting pull requests? This should simplify the review. E.g. this one has 'CAY-1942' in its history , which it really doesn't. We need to create a dev guide page on Git workflow I guess.

And I guess you can close this pull request, as it is fully applied.
I applied this one. If we still have problems, let's track them under a new pull request. I guess this one can be closed.

@AlexKolonitsky  : I split the pull request into general POM changes and CAY-1946 work. Applied the former to master, and then committed the rest to CAY-1946 branch with some minor cleanup described in fde7761f80ed8db65df3e157ab4acd5f47d75004 commit message:

https://github.com/apache/cayenne/tree/CAY-1946 
https://github.com/apache/cayenne/commit/fde7761f80ed8db65df3e157ab4acd5f47d75004

I like the new "load" configuration framework, but still need to wrap my head around it. Also one thing didn't work at all - Modeler reverse engineering: "Tools > Reengineer Database Schema" resulted in an empty DataMap. Perhaps default filters are off? 

So I guess we can close this pull request, and you can start working against  CAY-1946 branch and open a new pull request for new changes.

Applied. Nice job! "asfgit" process even closed the pull request automatically, since I committed it unchanged. The only thing that I noticed was that the diff had Windows line endings. Perhaps you need to adjust that in the IDE to be a UNIX '\n'. No big deal of course.

Everything merged well (and more importantly - worked well in my tests). Good stuff! I guess the next step would be to convert DICase/ServerCase/ClientCase to Junit 4 to take advantage of the 4 lifecycle.

Great job with '@RunWith(value=Parameterized.class) ' - this is exactly what was needed here. Everything is committed. As a bit of a nitpick, perhaps we should remove Assert as a superclass of everything. I realize we'll need a bunch of static imports, but I think that's still cleaner then a non-test superclass. And I guess a bulk static import that you had originally in each class is fine for the migration purposes: 

```
 import static org.junit.Assert.*;
```

I just committed the refactoring. I noticed though that all newly added files do not have proper Apache license headers. Let's maybe track them down and fix. You can use the rat.sh script in Cayenne root t trace those down. Release guide has a few words on how to run rat.sh: http://cayenne.apache.org/dev/release-guide.html
And I would highly recommend adding the license headers t your IDE templates for new Java classes.

I just committed the pull request. This is a good first pass. But let's discuss how to implement DbCleaner based on metadata, i.e. without hardcoding entity names and sequence of deletes.

Good stuff. Metadata-driven DbCleaner is what we need. A few small notes:
- 'DbCleaner.loader' is an ivar that is created and used in a single method, so probably needs to be a local var of that method. 
- Using 'setupAfterInjection' to call DbCleaner and then certain subclasses reimplementing it as an empty method to suppress DbCleaner call feels kind of dirty. Let's redesign this. Some ideas: add an extra  property to @UseServerRuntime annotation to enable/disable DbCleaner per test.

Also I got a bit impatient and added PEOPLE schema cleanup code to all tests that are using PEOPLE_PROJECT (via a common superclass). Let's see if that finally fixes the build.

I committed pull request to branch. The issue with catalog was resolved. There's still an issue with 'excludeTables':

```
<excludeTables>system_patch,v_*</excludeTables>
```

The above excluded "system_patch" table, but did not exclude a bunch of views named as "v_something". Not sure if it is significant that those were views , not tables.
